item.title: Ventura County sees increase in number of positive coronavirus cases among farmworkers
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: Before an outbreak at the Villa Las Brisas, farmworkers made up 2% of the county's overall case count. Now, these essential workers make up 7% of the county's total.
item.content:encoded: Before an outbreak at the Villa Las Brisas, farmworkers made up 2% of the county's overall case count. Now, these essential workers make up 7% of the county's total.

media:content.media:description: According to data from the U.S. Department of Agriculture, roughly half of all hired crop farm workers are in the country illegally. Above, workers pick strawberries in a Ventura field last month.

item.title: Charges against the social workers linked to Gabriel Fernandez's killing will be dropped
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Reyes-Velarde
item.description: Social workers Stefanie Rodriguez and Patricia Clement, and their supervisors, Kevin Bom and Gregory Merritt, were charged with child abuse and falsifying public records.
item.content:encoded: Social workers Stefanie Rodriguez and Patricia Clement, and their supervisors, Kevin Bom and Gregory Merritt, were charged with child abuse and falsifying public records.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 18, 2016: From left, defendant Stefanie Rodriguez, attorney Lance M. Filer, attorney Shelly B. Albert, defendant Gregory Merritt, defendant Patricia Clement, attorney Joseph Gutierrez, defendant Kevin Bom and his attorney Hagop Kuyumjian stand during the arraignment of two Los Angeles County social workers and their supervisors who are charged with child abuse and falsifying records stemming from the death of 8-year-old Gabriel Fernandez. The boy's mother, Pearl Fernandez, and her then-boyfriend, Isauro Aguirre, are awaiting trial on a capital murder charge in connection with the boy's death. (Michael Owen Baker / For The Times)
media:content.media:credit: Michael Owen Baker / For The Times

item.title: Megan Thee Stallion says she got shot in the Hollywood Hills. LAPD says it was a foot injury
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, Christi Carras
item.description: An LAPD account of the incident, in which recording artist Tory Lanez was arrested, makes no mention of the rapper being shot, only a foot injury.
item.content:encoded: An LAPD account of the incident, in which recording artist Tory Lanez was arrested, makes no mention of the rapper being shot, only a foot injury.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Aug. 26, 2019 file photo, Megan Thee Stallion arrives at the MTV Video Music Awards in Newark, N.J.. The rapper says she was shot multiple times, but expects to fully recover. The 25-year-old said in an Instagram post Wednesday that she had gunshot wounds from a crime committed against her Sunday with the intent to harm her and feels lucky to be alive. She did not say who shot her or why, and Los Angeles police had no immediate comment. (Photo by Charles Sykes/Invision/AP, File)

item.title: California campuses likely to remain closed amid coronavirus spike, state schools chief says
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Colleen Shalby
item.description: The ongoing discussion about what school will look like in the months ahead comes on the heels of a record-breaking day among the number of daily coronavirus cases reported in the state.
item.content:encoded: The ongoing discussion about what school will look like in the months ahead comes on the heels of a record-breaking day among the number of daily coronavirus cases reported in the state.

media:content.media:description: MAR VISTA, CA - JULY 13, 2020 - - A sign states, "We miss our Short Avenue Families," at the closed Short Avenue Elementary School in Mar Vista on July 13, 2020. Los Angeles campuses will not reopen for classes on Aug. 18, and the nation's second-largest school system will continue with online learning until further notice, because of the worsening coronavirus surge, Supt. Austin Beutner announced Monday. "Let me be crystal clear," Beutner said in an interview with The Times. "We all know the best place for students to learn is in a school setting." But, he said, "We're going in the wrong direction. And as much as we want to be back at schools and have students back at schools - can't do it until it's safe and appropriate." (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 32 stranded chimpanzees need permanent new homes
item.dc:creator: Louis Sahagun
item.description: More than 500 exotic animals have been relocated since the troubled Wildlife Waystation surrendered its permits and shut down for good a year ago.
item.content:encoded: More than 500 exotic animals have been relocated since the troubled Wildlife Waystation surrendered its permits and shut down for good a year ago.

media:content.media:description: SYLMAR, CA - JULY 14, 2020 - - One of the 32 chimpanzees that still resides at the shuttered Wildlife Waystation on World Chimpanzee Day in the Angeles National Forest in Sylmar on July 14, 2020. The fate of the chimpanzees is uncertain because reputable sanctuaries willing to take them lack the funding needed to give the animals permanent new homes, officials say. The challenge now is finding the roughly $7 million it will take to build accommodations for the chimps at four reputable sanctuaries across the nation. A fundraiser was announced to help the sanctuaries take on these chimpanzees and to assist with the current care expenses of the primates while they wait at the Wildlife Waystation. More than 500 exotic animals including lions, tigers, alligators, wolves, owls and Vietnamese pot-bellied pigs have been relocated since the troubled 44-year-old center surrendered its California Department of Fish and Wildlife permits and shut down a year ago. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Boy, 16, was given estrogen for behavioral disorder while in L.A. juvenile hall, suit alleges
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: A 16-year-old boy held in a Los Angeles juvenile hall was prescribed estrogen to treat a behavioral disorder, a practice several doctors say flies in the face of accepted medical doctrine, according to a lawsuit filed in late June. The boy developed enlarged breasts as a result and will need surgery, according to his attorney.
item.content:encoded: A 16-year-old boy held in a Los Angeles juvenile hall was prescribed estrogen to treat a behavioral disorder, a practice several doctors say flies in the face of accepted medical doctrine, according to a lawsuit filed in late June. media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Aug. 13, 2019, file photo, pedestrians walk through the gates of Harvard Yard at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass. Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology filed a federal lawsuit Wednesday, July 8, 2020, challenging the Trump administration's decision to bar international students from staying in the U.S. if they take classes entirely online this fall. Some institutions, including Harvard, have announced that all instruction will be offered remotely in the fall during the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. (AP Photo/Charles Krupa, File)

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - MAY 2, 2019. Brian Allen is on the CalGang database though he is not a gang member. item.title: Community fridges show up in L.A. neighborhoods to feed those in need
item.dc:creator: Julissa James
item.description: Across L.A., community refrigerators with free food are popping up as part of a mutual aid network that aims to feed the hungry and eliminate food waste.
item.content:encoded: Across L.A., community refrigerators with free food are popping up as part of a mutual aid network that aims to feed the hungry and eliminate food waste.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 12, 2020 - - Jonah Mock, 41, center, owner of Little Amsterdam Coffee shop, shows the food that has been donated to the community refrigerator, that rests in front of his Midtown establishment, as his son Nolan, 14, looks on in Los Angeles on July 12, 2020. The coffee shop provides the electricity for the refrigerator and is located at 1412 S Redondo Blvd. It is filled with milk, fruit, cheese, tortillas, vegetables and readymade meals all donated by community members. Community fridges are popping up all over Los Angeles as part of a mutual aid project to feed people in need during the coronavirus pandemic. The fridges are painted with murals and bright colors, and are stocked with food inside donated by people from the community, local food banks and restaurants. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Despite criticism, LAPD Chief Michel Moore maintains support in political circles
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector, Dakota Smith, Richard Winton
item.description: Los Angeles officials have repeatedly ignored a central demand of the activists and protesters who inspired their broader turn away from the status quo in policing: the termination of Los Angeles Police Chief Michel Moore.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles officials have repeatedly ignored a central demand of the activists and protesters who inspired their broader turn away from the status quo in policing: the termination of Los Angeles Police Chief Michel Moore.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - SEPTEMBER 28, 2018 - LAPD Chief Michel Moore talks to recruits during uniform inspection of this graduating class at the Los Angeles Police Department graduation exercises for Recruit Officer Class of April 16, 2018 happening at the LAPD Elysian Park Academy on September 28, 2018. Officer John Beaty talks about being an African American recruit and about why he joined the LAPD. In this class, three of the 34 graduates are African American (10 Caucasian, 21 Hispanic, no Asians). Much has been made of the LAPD's ethnic demographics roughly mirroring those of the city. But the impact of policing still falls disproportionately on black residents. The percentage of officers who are black - roughly 9% - will soon plummet. A huge number of black officers will soon retire and recent academy classes consistently have only a few black members. New Police Chief Michel Moore says black recruiting is one of his main priorities. But in the post-Ferguson era, theres a struggle to fight the forces discouraging young black people from becoming police officers. LAPD officers in the field today say they are facing unprecedented hostility from other black people, both in the field and at home, who view them as sellouts. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: MAR VISTA, CA - JULY 13, 2020 - - Pedestrians walk past the Grand View Boulevard Elementary School with a marquee that still reads, "No School," in Mar Vista on July 13, 2020. Los Angeles campuses will not reopen for classes on Aug. 18, and the nation's second-largest school system will continue with online learning until further notice, because of the worsening coronavirus surge, Supt. Austin Beutner announced Monday. "Let me be crystal clear," Beutner said in an interview with The Times. "We all know the best place for students to learn is in a school setting." But, he said, "We're going in the wrong direction. And as much as we want to be back at schools and have students back at schools - can't do it until it's safe and appropriate." (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Amid a national movement to defund the police, LAPD officers and their supporters rally outside headquarters
item.dc:creator: Cindy Chang
item.description: Officers say they are demoralized by the cuts, which will deliver a huge hit to overtime pay and hiring in the 10,000-member department, when they have worked hard to build ties with community members and are willing to risk their lives to keep people safe.
item.content:encoded: Officers say they are demoralized by the cuts, which will deliver a huge hit to overtime pay and hiring in the 10,000-member department, when they have worked hard to build ties with community members and are willing to risk their lives to keep people safe.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 11: LAPD officers form a line to separate pro- and anti-police demonstrators outside LAPD headquarters in downtown Los Angeles on Saturday, July 11, 2020. Hundreds of cops and their supporters held a morning rally to protest a $150 million cut in the city police budget. A handful of Black Lives Matter supporters showed up to counter them. (Luis Sinco / Los Angeles Times)

(Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: ANAHEIM, CALIF. - JULY 9, 2020. Scores of visitors descend of Downtown Disney in Anaheim for its reopening on Thursday, July 9, 2020. Officials required visitors to wear face coverings and practice social distancing. By 5:00 p.m. security guards closed the parking gate, saying that the shopping and dining complex had reached its capacity. Disney''s adjacent them parks remain closed. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)
